title: heroic young nurse saves bus
story: NewsHeroic young nurse saves bus drivers le after he has a heart attackAoe McGivney rushed to open the drivers cabin and stopped the bus before performing CPR on the unconscious driverShareByTfany Lo:,  MAR NewsMs McGivney managed to stop the bus and perform CPR on the driver "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn off-duty nurse in Dublin has been praised by passengers for saving a bus drivers le after spotting he had gone into cardiac arrest. Aoe McGivney, who works as a nurse at Mater Hospital, noticed the bus driver fell ill as he drove on the OConnell Bridge in Dublin city at around am on Monday. The quick-thinking nurse heard other passengers screaming as the bus started rolling. She rushed to the drivers seat and found the driver unconscious as she desperately tried to open the drivers cabin, she told The Hard Shoulder on Newstalk.  She added: We didnt knowit was going to go on the path or we didnt know it had already hit someone. Thank god the cyclist was okay and was fine and was able to jump away from the bus but that was unknown to us at the time. Ms McGivney was able to move the drivers leg off the accelerator and stop the bus immediately. Other passengers joined forces to get the driver off the bus. He was breathing at the time, I was checking his pulse but I could tell he wasnt conscious and he was pre-arrest so we were looking for signs that he was at risk of having a full cardiac arrest, she explained.Ms McGivney performed CPR on the driver until paramedics arrived the scene, reported Dublin Live.She was later told that the driver was alive and talking when he was taken away in an ambulance. She said it was important to have CPR training and first aid training in order to offer help in situations like this. Its so important for people to be aware of it because there was great people around that were able to join in and were able to shout, I have first aid training and they were able to help me, she said. A Dublin Fire Brigade spokesperson said: The driver is recovering well.

title: brexit what firms stockpiling what
story: NewsBrexit: These are what firms are stockpiling and what you should doSince we still dont know what will happen many firms are taking precautions to prevent disruption to their supply chainsShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsAll kinds of companies are stocking up"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Brexit uncertainty ramps up many firms have decided that they cant leave anything to chance.Instead they have decided to stockpile to avoid potential disruption and delays at the border in case of a no deal Brexit .In January it was reported that warehouse space in the UK was near capacity. While a recent survey found that British manufacturers are building up reserves at the fastest pace seen in any leading economy since the early . What you should do. Nothing. There is absolutely no need to stockpile food or medicines. In fact bulk buying could actually create shortages. The NHS   Health Secretary Matt Hancock has been accused of boasting about becoming the biggest purchaser of fridges. And the government has created a logistics hub in Belgium where vital medical supplies will be stockpiled to stop the NHS running short of equipmentthere is a no-deal Brexit. Stents, implants and other products needed to ensure that patient care is not disrupted will be stored at the hub. Perhaps more concerning is that the health service has begun stockpiling body bags. But theyre also keeping medicines, vaccines and blood products.  million packs of medicines are imported to the UK from the EU every month, and the NHS is preparing for a doomsday scenario to prevent supplies running dry. But crucially the NHS has insisted that no patients need to stock up on medicine.   AstraZenecahas increased the number of medicines available to pharmacies and hospitals in both the UK and EU by %. All in all the company has spent pound million preparing for no-deal including building labs in Sweden to duplicate product testing. French pharmaceutical giant Sanofihas acquired extra warehouse space in the UK for cold storage of medicines and vaccines. It is also moving some manufacturing operations from the UK to the EU. WHSmith   No one ever runs out of pens right  Well WHSmith is not taking any chances.Instead they are stockpiling six months worth of pens to guard against chaos at the border caused by Brexit .The stationers, who source most of their products from Asia, normally hold between three and four months worth of pens, diaries and notepads. But the boss of the British firm confirmed they were planning to hold six months worth to avoid disruptions to their supplies. Stephen Clarke, WHSmith’s chief executive, told Bloomberg: We’re used to holding quite a bit of forward cover in terms of stock anyway, so what we’ve done is topped that up a little bit to put ourselves in an even better position should there be congestion at ports.   Tesco Tesco chief executive, Dave Lewis, said the supermarket has been holding a talks with its suppliers and increasing stocks of long-le groceries. But, with Britain importing about half the fresh food it eats, Lewis said it was not possible to make similar arrangements for fresh foodBritain crashes out of the EU. “We looked at the lecycle and production of product categories that matter most to customers and sat down with all suppliers to discuss their production capability, where they hold stock andwe can help them hold it,” explained Lewis. “It’s not possible to do that sort of thing on fresh food, so that’s where the pinch point would bethere were to be a no-deal.”  Marks and Spencer Marks  Spencer said its own Brexit planning committee had “upped the ante” and started to make a “few real choices”. The chief executive, Steve Rowe, said: “We have taken some additional long-le stuff but our food business is % fresh and anything that slows down will contribute to cost and waste.”   Dixons CarphoneBritains biggest seller of electricals and mobile phones has said it is prepared for all Brexit scenarios.The group which imports most of its product from Asia had worked with suppliers to make sure disruption was minimised. Some of those had brought stock into the UK early. The companys finance chief said that being the market leader put it in a good position as suppliers were likely to prioritise the company - suggesting that smaller retailers might suffer. Airline food  Companies like Gate Gourmet, which supplies  airlines at  UK airports in the have begun stockpiling frozen main meals, pizzas, dried snacks and sandwiches at warehouses in Peterborough and London. Gate Gourmet produces most of its meals in Germany and Spain. They fear any holdup at the border could disrupt its business model. BMW  Hundreds of trucks carry car parts into the UK on a daily basis to be used in just-in-time supply chains at plants across the country. Manufacturers are concerned about disruption at the border but the way the supply chains work mean stockpiling isnt really a viable option. BMWCustoms Manager StephanFreismuth said that the company could only stockpile for a matter of days. He said that anything longer would require building “the highest building in the world.” “We are looking for additional [warehouse] space but in the end, it’s not possible. We are producing ‘just in time,’ and just in sequence,”Freismuth said, BMW imports about € billionworth of car parts from the EU every year, or double the amount it sources from inside the country. Nissan, Toyota and Honda face similar problems.  Pets at Home Britains biggest pet supplier has begun stockpiling cat and dog food. The chief executive Peter Pritchard has pledged to ensure families do not run out of food for their pets. It is particularly important since % of the companys supplies come from outside the UK. The firm said they were considering holding up to poundm worth. Bentley  The chief executive of Bentley said the company was stockpiling parts. He described Brexit as a “killer” threatening the profitability of the luxury carmaker.   Unilever is stockpiling ice creams in Britain to guard against potential supply disruptions in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The Anglo-Dutch consumer giant, which is the worlds largest ice cream seller, makes British favourites likeMagnumbars in Italy and Germany. It is building up a few weeks of extra stock in Britain in case of any border delays. Likewise, several of its European deodorants, including Axe, Dove and Rexona are made in Britain and transported to the continent. A few weeks of extra inventory is one of the important steps we are taking to make sure that we minimise any disruption to our customers and consumers, said Alan Jope, Unilevers new chief executive.

title: super nan 86 climbs out
story: NewsSuper nan, , climbs out her window to dismantle scaffolding spoiling her viewHazel Kampler decided to take matters into her own hands after being forced to live in darkness for seven monthsShareCommentsByAbbie BrayTfany Lo:,  MAR NewsPensioner Hazel Kampler was fed up living in darkness for seven months as the scaffolding blocked the lights "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pensioner has been hailed a hero by her neighbours as she climbed out of her window and dismantled scaffolding in protest after her view was obstructed. title: devastated mum jade mcgrath forgives
story: NewsDevastated mum of Jade McGrath forgives bullies who tormented her daughterSamantha Taylor asked the bullies to honour her daughter Jade McGrath who took her own le last November after suffering long-term mental problemsShareCommentsByTfany Lo:,  MAR NewsJade McGraths mum has shared an emotional message on Facebook"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grief-stricken mother has publicly forgiven the bullies who tormented her teenage daughter Jade McGrath. Samantha Taylor took to social media to describe the horric effect bullying had on her -year-old daughter, attached with a picture of the younger Jade along with a photo of her gravestone.In the y Facebook post, Samantha said she forgave them as they were too young to understand what they were doing.Jades body was found  days after she went missing from New Craigs Psychiatric Hospital in Inverness, Scotland in November.  Samantha wrote the post yesterday as she called out the bullies. She said: You know who you are. The damage that you did to her self esteem was profound and long-lasting. Although she fought hard and valiantly to over come the damage that you caused, in the end she lost her fight, just when she seemed to be finally turning a corner. She never got a chance to do her exams at Millburn because she was too terried to go to school. That meant no college, so no qualications, so she was forced to do unskilled low paid jobs. As a result of her sensitive gentle nature, she found it hard to recover from the bullying and abuse that you inflicted on her.   Jade has been described by her mother as a special and happy kid. But her mother also outlined that Jade was diagnosed with Borderline Personality Disorderas a result of the trauma. Despite all the pain Jade was put through Samantha said she forgives the bullies. In the Facebook post, she said: I also want you to know this: I forgive you. I forgive you, Because you were only young when you inflicted this damage, too young to understand what you were doing. Samantha stated that she was not writing it out of hatred or revenge but to ask them to honour her and her memory. I want you to always make the time in your le to help the people that you go to college or uni with, or work with, people like Jade, she wrote. Gentle, sensitive, quirky people who have trouble fitting in, or try too hard to fit in because they don’t think they are good enough just as they are. title: mum told hours live defied
story: NewsMum told she had HOURS to live but defied doctors and married love of her leMadeleine Wickett says she was called an enigma by doctors who told her daughters they were waiting for her heart to stopShareCommentsByLottie ONeill:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMadeleine asked the love of her le to marry her "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mother battling oian cancer was told she had just hours to live - but she defied doctors and has gone on to marry the love of her le.Madeleine Wickett, , was diagnosed in May  but during the summer months, her health deterioated.After she responded badly to a dose of chemotherapy treatment, doctors feared her body was shutting down, Essex Live reports.Her daughter Melissa told how the Chelmsford family were pulled into a side room and told your mum is not going to make it, Im really sorry she only has hours to live. The family say doctors kept telling them they were waiting for her heart to stop working and stopped all medicine and pain killers. But Madeleine fought on and recovered, leaving staff dumbfounded and leading them to call her an enigma, the family says. While the mum was being treated in hospital, her family refused to leave her side and her children, as well as her now-husband, Ray, slept beside her. And after she was discharged, Madeleine phoned Ray at work one day to ask him to marry her. Though she feared she may not make it to her wedding, she managed to walk down the aisle in November .  Madeleine, who is originally from North London, first suspected her health issues could have been Irritable Bowel Syndrome and visited herGP last year.She said: My doctor sent me for blood tests and when they were back, he said Im going to send you for a two-week referral, do you know what that means , and I dont knowit was a feeling or coincidence but I knew I had cancer. My mother died of cancer and my grandmother, who I never met, died of it too. Her daughter, Melissa Rimington, , remembers that when her mother was fighting the disease, she took a turn for the worst during the summer. She said: It was a hot summer and mum wasnt drinking very much anyway and she spiralled. Madeleine signed up for newchemotherapy treatmentas she wanted the opportunity to help others in the future whilst she was fighting herself. She was given a tester amount and reacted fine, so she started the full treatment. However, she soon began to feel unwell. That is when I was crashing, she added, I dont remember much, I dont remember anything, not even my doctor coming in or the ambulance. My family thought I was okay and that I was recognising everyone who was with me but they didnt realise at the time that my brain just shut down. Madeleine had responded badly to the full  per cent chemotherapy treatment and her body was shutting down. Melissa continued: After mum crashed, the doctor called us in at pm into the intensive care unit, pulled us into a room and basically said Your mum is not going to make it, Im really sorry she only has hours to live. Her kidneys and liver have shut down and we are just waiting for her heart to stop. We just wanted to be with her and comfort her, they kept coming in every  hours to tell us. Then after two days the doctor came back and said I think we need to do a few more tests, because they were expecting her to pass away  hours before. She added: All I kept thinking was that I’ve got to say goodbye to my mum. They put her onend-of-le careand they were just waiting for her heart to stop.” Miracle menopause cream deals with crippling symptoms - and works in seconds Doctors also offered Madeleine pain killers but she said she didnt need them, and staff were baffled and called her an enigma because they hadnt see this before, the mum says. Her daughter continued: It was a rollercoaster of emotions. We slept by Mum’s hospital bed for three solid weeks and I think I cried more in those three weeks than I’ve ever cried in my entire le.” Madeleine added: When I got ill my family slept around me, I was in a room and they were all by my bed in sleeping bags. They survived on sandwiches and fruit from MS and refused to leave my side. She began getting stronger and stronger, however she had lost four stone due to her three weeks in hospital. With her family at her side, including daughters Jojo, , and Katrina, , she was on the mend. After fighting back, Madeleine was put on a lower dose of chemotherapy treatment and the tumour shrunk. When Madeleine was back at home, she was still growing stronger but was too weak to walk on her own. One day, she saw an advert for a wheelchair loan from The Red Cross and showed Melissa, as they were not sure where to go for help. They went to pick up the wheelchair and when they got it home, Melissa took her mum out for the first bit of fresh air that she had felt in a long time after being left housebound through her recovery. It was only a few days after being discharged in September that she decided it was time to ask her partner, Ray, of  years, to tie the knot. I called him up at work, he is a commercial boiler engineer so he must have been knee deep in the stuff, Madeleine said. And I said, Its just a quick one, would you want to marry me  and he replied, without hesitation yes, so I said okay then, Ill see you when you get home later.   After Ray accepted her proposal, she began planning the wedding straight away to get wed in November. Madeleine and her daughters did most of the wedding planning, but Ray chose the first dance song as Angel by Robbie Williams, after telling her that whenever he hears that song he thinks of her. For some time, she was worried that she might not make it for the wedding. I told my daughters thatI dont make it, to not cancel anything and have the day as a wake, Madeleine said. But she did make it and even better - she walked down the aisle. On November , , the couple made it official at Orsett Hall,Thurrock. Although the wheelchair was there for the day and during the all-important wedding dress shopping trips, Madeleine walked down the aisle to meet Ray waiting for her. That wheelchair was a godsend, the -year-old said. AndI hadn’t seen that advert I don’t know what we would have done. I was housebound before. The wheelchair helped me to get outside, in the sunlight and the fresh air. We were really worried that Mum wasn’t going to be able to walk down the aisle,says Melissa.The wheelchair took a lot of pressure off. Mum wouldn’t have been able to do it without it. The next step to Madeleines recovery mayinclude a hysterectomyas she awaits consultation with her doctor. This can aid the mum to continue on her road to recovery. When I finally come round, I didnt understand why I lived because I shouldnt have, said Madeleine, Im now thinking I will tell my story to help others. Michael Lascelles, British Red Cross mobility aids hub manager responsible for Essex, says:British Red Cross believes everyone who needs a wheelchair should be able to get one that is right for them to help with their recovery, and the tireless efforts of our volunteers help to make this possible. We are so proud to have been a part of Melissa and Ray’s special day and we wish them every happiness for the future. If you would like to find out more about volunteering to help other people like Madeleine adjust after illness or injury, contact Ben Weatherburn at bweatherburn@redcross.org.uk

story: NewsStunned young couple, , have TWO sets of twins  years apart - both by accidentJessica Phoenix and Liam McMahon, from Kent, admit both pregnancies were a surprise but that they wouldnt change anythingShareCommentsByLaura ElvinJane Lavender:,  MAR NewsJessica and Liam with Harry and Elijah and Phoebe and Aria "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email When Jessica Phoenix and Liam McMahon found out they were to become parents they were absolutely delighted. But then, just two years later, when they discovered they were about to become mum and dad a second time round they couldnt believe it when they were told they were having a SECOND set of twins .The family is now made up of Jessica, Liam, Harry and Elijah, aged two, and their twin girls, Phoebe and Aria, who arrived last September. It was four unexpected babies, but now I wouldnt change it for the world. Chef Liam added: To think that Im a dad of four does feel pretty crazy.   People my age are usually living at home with their mum and dad, just thinking about going out or going to uni. Having them has made me want to do more in my le. It makes me want to make them proud. The pair met at work in Wetherspoons four years ago, aged , and admit they werent very good with contraceptives. Bar manager Jessica broke the first pregnancy news to Liam by joking she would have to buy him a Fathers Day card. But while they both have twins in their families, they never imagined theyd have twins until they saw two shapes on the sonogram at the  week scan. The pair admit le was crazy while they got used to Harry and Elijah, who arrived via c-section, on February , , at  weeks, weighting lb oz, and lb oz. Jess said: Id only just got used to the idea of having one baby when I found out it was two.  It was a bit overwhelming. I wanted boys so I was glad to find out it was boys. With the boys I think I was just getting used to being a mum so it felt I was always trying to keep up - doing one thing then the next then the next, whether it was nappies or bottles. But now I know they are fine, I know what Im doing. This time I know what to do. The couple confess they were happy as a family of four and had no plans to have more children. But Jessica found out she was pregnant again just after her sons had turned two and the couple said they were pleased to be having one more. Doctors made the decision to perform a C-section early. Phoebe and Aria were born on September , six weeks early both weighing lb oz. Both sets of twins are non identical. Liam said: In some ways it has been easier with four than two. With the boys, because we had just got together and we were so young, Jessica would get looks. Haringkan Samuelsson, Volvo’s president and chief executive, said: “While a speed limitation is not a cure-all, it’s worth doingwe can even save one le. The European Union is considering requiring whats known as Intelligent Speed Assistance on new cars sold there by . Guests are nicely boozed, but not sloppy drunk. Theres often laughter and tears and, of course, a chilled glass of bubbly.On occasion, however, the speeches are memorable for all the wrong reasons. Just ask this seriously disgruntled bride... The bride in question got married last Saturday and her maid of honour, her sister, gave a long speech which got her booted out of the wedding.   So how bad was it  Decide for yourself...Taking to Reddit , the bride said: During her speech, she brought up her depression and how my husband supported her through it and how in that moment, I knew he was the one for me... .I thought her speech was really selfish. I think its super inappropriate to bring up a mental illness during a wedding speech. Not only that, but the entire speech was about her. At MY wedding. Ninety per cent of the guests congratulated her afterwards and talked about how strong she was.   Nobody was paying attention to me, at my own wedding! SorryI sound selfish, but in my opinion there is a time and a place for this sort of thing. So after the guests all greeted her, I asked her to leave and told her she was being disruptive and selfish. She was really upset but just left without arguing. My parents agree with me. But my husband and all of my close friends think I was way too harsh. If the bride was after tea and sympathy, she was barking up the wrong tree. While some people did agree the sister had made a bit of a bad move, plenty of others called the bride out for how she handled it.  The lack of compassion for mental illness is also quite apparent in both the bride and her parents, one comment read. Someone  added: Also, does she not realise this is now the one thing people will remember about her wedding  How she went all jealous gorilla and locked her sister out. Like, wow. Theyre gonna talk about this for years. She seems more upset not every second was focused on her than about the speech itself, another comment agreed. Maybe her sister didnt give the best speech of the year but she certainly doesnt sound disruptive.

story: NewsSchoolboys save child, , with makesht net after he plunges from ski ltQuick-thinking Joshua Ravensbergen, , and his friends were on the slopes at Grouse Mountain near Vancouver, Canada, when the boy slipped from his seatShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video unedited-video-boy-clinging-chairlt-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFive schoolboys caught a terried eight-year-old in a makesht safety net after he dropped from a ski lt. Quick-thinking Joshua Ravensbergen, , and his friends were on the slopes below when the boy slipped from his seat and his dad caught him by the wrist. He said the lt kept going higher and higher until it was too late for the boy to jump to safety. Joshua said they feared he would be hurtthey did not do something to help as adults stood by, so they grabbed the orange fencing and some padding from a pillar and rushed beneath the chairlt. When the boy could no longer hold on, he let himself fall and was safely caught by the boys, who were about ft below.   Joshua said: “People were there but were just standing looking at the kid, not knowing what to do.” The drama was caught on video at Grouse Mountain near Vancouver, Canada. Joshua’s friend Gabriel Nielson said it took some time to convince the boy to kick off his skis and let go of his father.   “At one point, we were just like, ‘OK, you just need to trust us, you just need to drop,” said Gabriel. The child was on the chairlt was with his parents and his three-year-old sister, who the father was also trying to hang on to while struggling to cling to his son. A Grouse Mountain Resorts spokeswoman said the boy was uninjured but went to hospital as a precautionary measure.

title: brentford arab to cycle from dundee uniteds tannadice ground to london
story: A football friendship that kicked off with a chance meeting in a Berlin bar while watching Andy Murray win Wimbledon will see a Brentford fan literally get on his bike at Tannadice today and cycle almost  miles back “home” to the London club’s Grfin Park.In the process, Steve Tidy will take in four games and, most important of all, raise around £, for the Alzheimer’s Trust.The -year-old has travelled north to meet up with good mate Pat McCarron, who’s well-known among Arabs as chairman of the group Fans United, and took in the Scottish Cup clash with Inverness Caley before setting off this morning.And his arduous route south is all down to that friendship.“It was back in  and Brentford were in Berlin for pre-season. Myself and a mate were looking for somewhere to watch the tennis and, by chance, we met up with Pat and a few other United fans,” he said. “We had a good bit of banter and we’ve kept in touch since.”The friendship with Pat and other United fans actually led to the formation of a unique supporters’ club, the BeeArabs, so when Steve was planning his latest charity bike ride, this seemed an obvious route to take.“We thought it would be a good idea to start at Tannadice and head for Grfin Park. I had actually planned it as a practice run before I cycle from London to Paris and back via Guernsey in the summer, but this might be an even bigger task.“That said, my biggest challenge could be surviving the weekend with Pat before I set off on the bike!”Once he’s on his way, Steve will complete the journey in stages and take in Brentford games at Middlesbrough and Sheffield United before arriving at Grfin Park just in time for the clash with West Brom later this month.And thanks to the support he’s already receiving, he hopes to pass a personal milestone with his fund- raising efforts.“I got into cycling a few years back and I’ve done a charity ride to Amsterdam to raise money. It’s a great way to stay fit and, by the time I’ve completed this journey, I should have raised around £, in all for a few charities, so that’s not bad.“I am loving the support I am getting from all in Dundee. It’s overwhelming how many nice people there are from Dundee to Durham, Hartlepool to Leeds, Sheffield to London.”

title: dundee duo set up bakery specialising in birthday cakes for dogs
story: Two Dundee friends have opened a bakery specialising in making birthday cakes for dogs.Cheryl Walker, , and Amy Plummer, , have been inundated with orders since opening Dundee Dog Kitchen – sparking what they hope will be a new trend in the pet world.Cheryl, who lives in Fintry, said she had the idea after struggling to find a fresh cake for her own collie Tess’s first birthday.She said: “I wanted to throw Tess a party and give her a big treat.“I wanted to get her a cake but I couldn’t find anything.“I ended up ordering a cake online which came wrapped in cellophane and had a six-month shelf le – there just wasn’t anyone making anything fresh.”Cheryl and Amy joined forces to fill the gap in the market and opened their pet bakery in December.Their cakes are sugar-free and are packed with carrots, yoghurt, honey, peanut butter and other healthy ingredients which are all locally produced and contain health benefits for the dogs.Amy, who lives in Lochee, said: “We get a mixed reaction when we tell people what we’re doing, but dog lovers are very enthusiastic about it.“It’s taken off really quickly which is all a bit bizarre but very exciting.”Pet owner Imogen Hynd, , couldn’t wait to get a special carrot cake made for her black Labrador Skye on her first birthday.Imogen, of Broughty Ferry, said: “We wanted to mark the occasion because we love her to bits – she’s our little fur baby.“She’s part of the family. You’d do that for a human member of the family, so why not do it for a dog too “We wanted to treat her because she deserves it.”And it seems pet owners across the city agree. Dundee Dog Kitchen has had  birthday cake orders over the next two months.It sold  Valentine “pupcakes” and  Christmas cakes at its launch.Cheryl added: “We’re in a new age of pet ownership where people treat their dogs like family, which is why I think our idea has really caught on.”

title: dundee residents urged to apply for money to bring community projects to life
story: Douglas youngsters are being encouraged to apply for funding to see their own community projects come to le.A youth bank scheme has been set up by the East End community organisation RockSolid.Co-ordinator Mary Richmond said the youth bank group is made up of young people who fundraise through a number of community based activities.She said: “They raise money by selling arts and crafts at local stalls to fund things which benefit the community.“It’s completely up to them how they raise the money.“We have about £, in the pot at the moment which gives them the opportunity to do whatever benefits the community.”She added: “The projects could be anything from buying a laptop for young people to do homework at after school clubs, to putting dog bags in local parks.“We have also done training around money management with the group.“We want to get more applications in – people don’t realise it’s free money and costs nothing to put your application in.“Obviously you have to say how your project will improve the community and prove where the money is going.”Mary added applications to get money from the youth bank are open all year round for people living in Douglas.Grants of up to £ can be applied for to put the projects in action, as long as there are two young people aged between - involved in the process.Applications are paper-based and can be picked up at Douglas and Mid Craigie Church on Balbeggie Place.It comes as the group is giving budding young photographers the chance to develop their skills.New group sessions will run throughout the next school term and a professional photographer has been enlisted to help.The team meets every Monday from -pm at the church.

title: dundees rich and varied history to be discussed in series of events
story: Dundee’s rich and ied history will be the subject of a series of talks this week.Everything from the city’s involvement in Arctic whaling, to its lunatic asylum, and the history of Stobswell will be covered in talks which begin tonight.The first of the presentations will be Finding Stobswell’s Story, held in Arthurstone Library at .pm today.Leisure and Culture Dundee’s Kevin McGinley said: “At tonight’s talks, visitors will learn about the history of Arthurstone Library and the Stobswell area.“We’ll hear about the area from its origins as a small hamlet to its le as part of bustling, industrial Dundee, taking in the origins of Stobswell institutions like the Morgan and Baxter Park.”He said the talks will continue at Lochee Community Library tomorrow with a discussion led by Andrew Murray Scott, on the rich, daily le of Dundee.Mr McGinley added: “Andy will recall important events and iniduals, offering keen insights into the processes of development and recovery and painting a graphic portrait of the modern city and its people.”On Thursday at St Andrew’s Church on King Street, Morag Allan Campbell – a PhD student studying at St Andrews University – will explore how case notes and records from Dundee Lunatic Asylum can help us to hear the voices of th Century women.The talk is based on the research she has carried out using records at Dundee University Archives.Also on Thursday, at The McManus, there will be a talk on th Century Dundee’s exotic animal trade.Mr McGinley said: “Dundee’s th Century economy relied heavily on the trade of animals for products and services.“As Dundee rose to a position of prominence in Arctic whaling, the city also emerged as a vibrant and internationally-recognised emporium for collection and exchange of exotic animals – both dead and alive.”On Friday, there will be a rare opportunity at the Steps Theatre to see a film specially made for Dundee’s  celebrations in .On Saturday, Malcolm Archibald will speak at the Central Library on Dundee’s past in the Arctic whaling industry.

story: A CITY bakery looks set to make way for a hip new bar in Inverness city centre.The Ashers bakery chain has confirmed this week that it is "at an advanced stage of negotiations" over vacating its premises in Church Street to make way for Aberdeenshire-based BrewDog.It was revealed last month that the pub chain, which has grown rapidly in the past few years and now employs more than  staff in dozens of bars across the UK, was keen to come to the Highland capital.While there has been no official confirmation from BrewDog itself Ali Asher, joint managing director of the Ashers chain, confirmed talks are progressing."Its clearly a very good site for that type of operation now," he said, adding that Ashers itself will not be leaving the city centre but simply moving."We have also identied a location round the corner on Union Street which we plan to relocate to at the same time," he said."We hope the necessary consents and assistance from the authorities and our local tradesmen will facilitate this being a smooth transition."Mr Asher also revealed plans for a refurbishment of his chains cafe at the Farraline Park bus station."We look forward to welcoming many loyal and new customers to both these shops and wish BrewDog all the best," he added.BrewDog was launched in Fraserburgh in  by friends Martin Dickie and James Watt, both then , with a mission to increase interest in craft beer.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Demolition of Eastgate Hostel to start soon
story: EVERY effort will be made to keep disruption to a minimum during the long-awaited demolition of an eyesore in Inverness city centre.Work is set to begin on Monday to take down the scaffolding and frontage of the former Eastgate Hostel which has been a blot on the landscape since being gutted by a blaze in April .Inverness city centre manager David Haas said representatives from Highland Council and the Inverness Business Improvement District have been liaising with the agents to work out a programme to ensure the work happens with the least disruption.There would be a temporary narrowing of the thoroughfare to enable the work to be carried out as quickly and effectively as possibly.ldquoWe are working closely with the business community so they understand the need for the works and that we are taking steps to minimise the disruption so as not to prejudice theof their businesses, Mr Haas said.Businesses would still be able to welcome people through their doors.ldquoAs a member of the public you will be able to walk up and down unhindered, he stressed.Talks have also taken place to ensure access for emergency services and deliveries.ldquoEveryone will understand this is an important moment for the High Street and the city, he said. ldquoWe want to give the opportunity to take the building down as quickly and efficiently as possible.The demolition is expected to take  weeks. The plan is for each stone at the front to be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.ldquoI am very pleased that at long last we are going to see activity which is positive and aon the High Street to a usable site in that area, Mr Haas said.ldquoWe are all conscious we have to maintain a proper service to the public. We will not lose sight of that.ldquoThe agents and the contractor are very committed to getting this job done to the highest professional standard.The demolition follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which ensured the story remained in the headlines.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Firms are urged to prepare for Brexit
story: BUSINESSES in the Highlands and Islands are not doing enough to prepare for the impact of Brexit, Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas warned.More than two-thirdsof firms who took part in the agencyrsquos latest business  survey in September and October highlighted Brexit as one the main risks they face, with only  per cent believing it posed no risk to their business.Despite this, the survey showed that only  per cent of firms have a plan in place to help them prepare for Brexit, and a fthrecognise that they need to develop a plan.Carroll Buxton, HIErsquos director of regional development, said: ldquoWhile there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how Brexit will affect businesses in the region, some are already taking steps to prepare, and we would encourage others to do so.ldquoThere is help available on the Prepare for Brexit website and from our own website. Through these, businesses can access expert advice to help them plan, including a handy -point Brexit checklist.More than a thirdof businesses that took part in the survey were trading internationally, but respondents had mixed views on the importance to their business of access to the European Single Market. Just over halfregarded this as important while  per cent said it is not important. However, a higher proportionconsidered the single market important to the Scottish economy overall.The free movement of people across the EU was also viewed as important to the Scottish economy by  per cent of respondents, yet only two in fivefelt it was important to their own business.In addition to questions on Brexit and international trade, the business  survey covered other core issues such as economic confidence, business performance and optimism.Almost two thirdssaid they were confident in the regionrsquos economy and  per cent were optimistic about their own performance and prospects.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Keep Safe scheme signs up new Highland sites
story: FRIGHTENED people seeking refuge now have more safe zones in which to get support in Nairn.Police Scotland and the I Am Me charity have welcomed new members to the arearsquos Keep Safe network, which gives people a place to gothey feel frightened, distressed or have been the victim of crime.Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau has joined the initiative, which is delivered in partnership between I Am Me and Police Scotland.The Keep Safe project aims to help people with a disability, feel safe within their community.I Am Me is a community partnership charity developed in Renfrewshire, to raise awareness of Disability Hate Crime.Gill Maclean, manager of Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been approved as a Keep Safe space and are keen to do all we can help vulnerable people feel safer and, therefore, more likely to venture out into the town.Inspector Judy Hill told the Courier: ldquoThis initiative aims to help vulnerable members of our communities, including the elderly and the disabled, to feel safe and know where to go for help and assistance should they require it.ldquoAll Keep Safe places are approved by Police Scotland.ldquoSometimes due to disability or age-related illness, people can easily become disorientated, lost or become confused, especially in and around unfamiliar surroundings.ldquoKeep Safe can offer a reassurance that there is somewhere people can seek assistancerequired.For more details about the scheme, go online at www.iammescotland keep-safe about-keep-safe Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Loch Ness Monster the subject of new master pie ce
story: To celebrate British Pie Week, pastry specialists Jus-Rol decided to create an art pie-ce of Nessie out of pies.The image is made up of more than  handmade pies, using a combination of shortcrust, puff and filo pastry.The masterpiece took three days to create and cocoa powder, currants, sesame seeds, caster sugar and brown sugar were used for the outlining and some of the detailing.Holly Bouldin from Jus-Rol says, ldquoJus-Rol, British Pie Week aims to inspire the nation to celebrate one of the greatest British classic foods and we wanted to pay tribute to that love by creating an impressive image which is synonymous with Scotland.As well as the artwork, Jus-Rol ran a UK-wide poll ahead of pie week, which runs next week. It uncovered that the average Scot eats three pies a month and Scotlandrsquos all-time favourite flavour was beef and ale.The poll also showed that one in  Scots bake a homemade pie twice a month. Andthere isnrsquot a rolling pin to hand Scottish people are the most likely, in the UK, to reach for a wine bottle as an alternative.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Shock at extent of tree felling by the Caledonian Canal in Inverness
story: Councillor Duncan Macpherson believes too many trees have been chopped down to make way for the latest phase of the Inverness West Link.Oak trees have been brought down along the canal side to make way for a second swing bridge and poplar trees along the edge of the A at Glenurquhart Road have also been felled in the name of health and safety.Cllr Macpherson said he and many others were shocked to see the extent of the felling.He said: ldquoI can understand the need to have one or two trees down for the new swing bridge but it seems to me like theyrsquove just gone and taken every single tree down. Did they really need to do that ldquoI wouldnrsquot exactly call myself a tree-hugger but Irsquom thinking lsquoguys come on, are you sure you needed to take that many down rsquoInverness musician Roderick Mackenzie, who lives nearby and is concerned about protecting the environment, said it made him feel ill to see mature trees being cut down.ldquoThis is abuse of the environment, he said. ldquoItrsquos sickening.A council spokesman said it was ldquoalways troubling to see mature trees removed but insisted the scale of the operation was necessary.And he said an environmental survey had been carried out before the felling started to rule out the presence of bird nests, bat roosts and similar habitats in the trees.He added: ldquoThe poplar trees adjacent to the A were in very poor condition and would have needed signicant reductions or complete removal, regardless of the development.ldquoPart of the stage two works will develop park land and there is a comprehensive replanting plan incorporated into the works commencing later this year.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: Ski slope plan for ex quarry outside Inverness
story: Inverness Snowsports Centrehas been told by Highland Council that it does not require an environmental impact assessmentat this stage for the proposed development at Torvean on the A Loch Ness road.ISC was formed by a group of snowsports and mountain bike enthusiasts who believe Inverness should have a venue for such activities for all ages and abilities.Project manager Helen Morgan said they envisage all-year-round attractions including mountain biking, zip wires, high rope trails and downhill tubing, all based around a snowsports core. It is estimated a pound million to pound million investment is required.The plan includes a building for catering, changing and hire of equipment, plusrooms available for rent.Panoramic viewing areas will be provided from where the sporting activities can be observed in comfort.The council has been told there will be ldquonegligible noise or light pollution as most of the development would be below the top rim of the quarry. There will be some removal of scrub trees and gorse and brambles, but mature trees will not be felled.The area is a Site of Special Scientic Interest as it is formed by an esker, an unusual geological feature where a long ridge of gravel and other sediment has been deposited by meltwater from a retreating glacier or ice sheet. It is one of the reasons gravel extraction was halted back in the s.The area is now used by dog walkers, ramblers, motorbike scramblers and X off-road fans.Inverness Snowsports Centre has launched an online Just Giving plea to raise pound, to pay for the studies required to support a formal planning application.Keen skier Miss Morgansaid they wanted to ensure people of all abilities had access to the activities.Cllr Bill Boyd, Inverness West, said: ldquoThis plan sounds quite exciting, but I hope they can come up with funding because the council is not in a position to fund it at the moment.ldquoIt could be an ideal centre for local people, schools and visitors.Tuesday  Mar  : AM

title: aberdeen charity charlie house launches new partnership with teca
story: An Aberdeen children#s charity has announced a two-year partnership with a major new concert venue.Charlie House, which supports children and young people with complex disabilities and le- limiting conditions, has secured a deal with state-of-the-art The Event Complex Aberdeen .A vital link for the city charity, it will also see the exhibition centre create a dedicated changing place for families with children with complex disabilities.TECA, which will replace the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre , is on track to open in summer this year at its new location in Bucksburn.Susan Crighton, director of fundraising at Charlie House, said: “We are thrilled to announce this key partnership for   and very much look forward to working with the team. Our corporate partnerships are vital to enable us to continue to deliver and expand our services to support families both in Aberdeen City and Shire and the wider north-east of Scotland.”Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local charlie-house-launches--million-appeal-to-build-specialist-care-centre-for-north-east-children embed # secretMttFeRTBR" data-secret"MttFeRTBR" width"" "" title"#Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Louise Stewart, the arena’s head of entertainment, sales and marketing, said: “The new venue is set to make concert attendance much more accessible for the families who are supported by Charlie House with a specic changing place being installed, which is essential to enable the families to spend extended time away from home.“We are also thrilled to continue to be part of Attitude is Everything, which improves deaf and disabled people’s access to live music by working in partnership with audiences, artists and the music industry to implement a charter of best practice across the UK, while we work towards achieving our gold standard.”The charity is currently raising £ million to build the first specialist support centre in the north-east.

title: aberdeen couple launch uks first hemp infused spirits
story: The couple behind an Aberdeen hemp oil company are launching a UK first by infusing the plant in gin and rum.Rebecca, , and Calum Napier, , owners of the award-winning Wee Hemp Company, have launched The Wee Hemp Spirits.The pair are passionate about the plant and its other uses after finding Cannabidioloil had benefits in the treatment of Rebecca’s chronic Crohn’s disease and fibromyalgia syndrome . The conditions mean she can only drink one or two alcoholic drinks occasionally, so the couple wanted to create something she could enjoy and savour, but also tackle the binge-drinking culture.Called Canna’B, the drinks will be available from Wednesday, while a CBD-infused limited edition will be released next month.The name, which came to Rebecca in her sleep, stems from Canna from the cannabis plant, and the ‘b’ at the end of the spirits is from the honey used to create the new drink.Rebecca and Calum also believe they have a world’s first after ageing the rum with the hemp plant for  days.Calum said: “Wee Hemp Spirits came along when Rebecca, myself and our dog were walking in the Cairngorms.“As people know, we are very fond of hemp and its many uses and we were looking to see how we could marry the hemp plant with spirits.“It hit us to combine hemp with a gin and a rum.Both contain our hemp seeds and our hemp plant material. We have also used award-winning honey from Royal Deeside inside the gin and the rum, as well as ancient spring water from the Cairngorms.“This has been going on since July  and we originally wanted to release them before Christmas, but we didn’t want to rush them and we wanted to make sure they were spot-on. We have done small batches and have  bottles of each for the first run.“With our rum we have aged it in charred hemp stocks which is a world first. It gives it a smoky and subtly sweet flavour.” The husband and we are aiming to break the stigma surrounding hemp. Rebecca said: “We want to showcase the hemp plant and our passion for it.“We wanted to create a drinking experience like no other, one that can be savoured and enjoyed.“We have used it in the CBD but it has so many other uses and it is one of the key things we want to try to get across to people.“It can be used as a botanical in the ageing process.#This is the start of our new business adventure and we’ll look at other ways it could be possibly used.“We want to break down that stigma and use amazing local produce for the spirits.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

story: NewsFamilys new hope as £, is raised to send son to America for cerebral palsy treatmentThe six-year-old will be heading to America after the huge sum of money was raised to fund his treatment.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  MAR NewsSaul with brothers Clay and Mylo and mum and dad, Karen and Stuart "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family’s bid to help their son walk again is set for take-off. Little Saul Wylie will travel to America for le-changing treatment on his severe form of cerebral palsy. The six-year-old, who weighed just lb at birth, has made the waiting list for pioneering surgery. There has been a massive charity effort across Ayrshire to fund the trip, with pound, raised in little over six months.Mum Karen, , told the Ayrshire Post : “To achieve this so quickly is beyond our wildest dreams.“We set a target of two years to get the money but the community reaction has been incredible.” Saul, of Tarbolton, has to go to the States because his aggressive condition is not treated on the NHS. The brave kid lives with spastic diplegia cerebral palsy, which affects his muscle tone and leaves him unable to walk unaided. Karen said: “Saul’s dream is to be able to stand by himself and take independent steps and maybe even one day walk around school with his friends. “Like every parent, we long for endless opportunities for our boy. “Saul is very happy and determined but we just want him to have the best opportunity at a better quality of le and to become as independent as possible.”  Medication, Botox, and even trampoline therapy have all been used to try and limit Saul’s pain. But his spot at St Louis Children’s Hospital in Missouri could be the ultimate answer. Karen said: “The operation is called selective dorsal rhizotomy, which will reduce Saul’s muscle stfness. “Added to intensive rehab, it will allow Saul to stand independently and potentially walk again. Unfortunately there is a waiting list for international patients so Saul’s surgery is not scheduled until . “But because we are in a position to go we have been put on their cancellation list and are keeping our fingers crossed.” Karen and husband Stuart have thrown themselves into a string of fundraising events with the ‘Steps For Saul’ campaign gathering momentum. Karen said: “We’ve done everything from coffee mornings to quiz nights and we can’t thank people enough for their response. “There have been skyes, race nights, sponsored cycles and I also did the Great Scottish Run. “People have taken Saul to their hearts and we’ve even had donations from as far afield as America, New Zealand, Canada and Ireland. “Hopefully he now has the chance he deserves.” • An open ice skate for Saul will take place at Ayr Ice Rink on Sunday, April , from -pm.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnDrugsCerebral palsyCharityAyr NewsAyr

title: tributes paid mr gaiety ayr
story: NewsTributes paid to Mr Gaiety as Ayr theatre legend Bernard Cotton diesBernard Cotton was a do-it-all theatre manager in the Gaietys pomp and booked acts like Billy Connolly, Ken Dodd and Barbara Windsor.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsBernard outside his beloved Gaiety "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe man who was ‘Mr Gaiety’ in Ayr for nearly two decades has died suddenly, aged , writes Edwin Lawrence. Bernard Cotton was at Alloway Bowling Club when he collapsed and died on Thursday last week. He had been club champion on ious occasions, the last time in . But it was as manager of the Gaiety from  to  that Bernard made his biggest impact. He took over at a critical time when the theatre’s ownership passed from the Popplewell family to the Royal Burgh of Ayr. But Bernard was the perfect man for the job, having managed the Empire Theatre in his home town of Sunderland. There he had hosted shows featuring The Beatles and Hollywood legend Marlene Dietrich. “He even shared a McEwan’s Export with Marlene,” said son Sam, . “They didn’t have any champagne to give Marlene so she had what dad was drinking - only with ice.”. Bernard was no ordinary theatre manager and often directed big showpiece events like pantos and summer season shows. He quickly became respected by some of the biggest names on the Scottish scene. He booked acts like Jimmy Logan, Billy Connolly, Rikki Fulton, Jack Milroy and perennial Gaiety favourite Johnnie Beattie. Bernard also knew some of the biggest UK stars, bringing Ken Dodd, Barbara Windsor, Pat Phoenix and Lionel Blair to the Gaiety.  He did not shy away from tough decisions, booking the controversial erotic revue ‘Oh! Calcutta!’ in . He later recalled: “It brought much adverse publicity and even the poster was frowned upon - to such an extent that the management agreed to cover over the female posterior that was displayed upon it.” However, the show was a massive financial success with only two unsold seats in a week-long run. Sam remembers his dad sharing a story of a couple walking out of the show in high dudgeon. Bernard asked them why, as it had been advertised as an X-rated show. The shocked couple told him they thought they had booked to see ‘Oklahoma!’. Another of Bernard’s controversial - but highly successful - bookings was ‘The Rocky Horror Show’, which attracts enthusiastic fans who often dress in stockings, corsets and suspenders. For although Bernard principally ran a family theatre, he believed it should cater for all tastes. A post on the Gaiety Facebook page says: “We are deeply saddened to hear about the loss of Bernard Cotton, a much loved colleague, dedicated family man and friend to all. “Bernard was and is a Gaiety institution, from his own time managing our Old Lady to helping us shape her future. We simply couldn’t have done it without his support. “His guidance, golden nuggets from years gone by, witty humour and love for delivering high-quality theatre for all were second to none. He will be sorely missed by us all. “At this sad time we are thinking of his beloved we Vida and children Julia and Sam. “We wish them moments of peace and comfort as they remember a husband, father and friend who was so cherished. “He will forever be in our hearts and minds and will always have a place in his beloved theatre.”  Musician Martin Henderson commented: “Bernard was witty, professional and a family man, a privilege to have worked for many years in the Gaiety while Bernard and Vida were at the helm. “He ran a tight ship but embraced risky ventures like our annual mock panto, which needs no explanation to Gaiety staff. A sad loss to Scottish theatre and his family.” Journalist Alistair Nicol said: “I met Bernard when I was deputy editor of the Ayrshire Post in  and he was always helpful and a great inspiration to all around him in the entertainment world.” Bernard Cotton was a former president of the Rotary Club of Ayr He is survived by we Vida, a stalwart Gaiety volunteer who formerly ran the theatre’s costume department London-based daughter Julia, , a former dancer and Brighton-based son Sam. His funeral service is at noon on Wednesday, March , at Masonhill Crematorium.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnBilly ConnollyFacebookThe BeatlesAyrSocial mediaAyr News

story: A DRUG dealer from Hawick who sold ecstasy tablets to two -year-olds has been told he could have been facing a murder charge.The schoolboys fell ill after taking taking the pills which contained compounds of the class A drug and required urgent medical treatment.Despite being born with no arms, Jake Moffett overcame his disability by supplying the ecstasy tablets to the two youngsters and pleaded guilty to a drug dealing charge at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Sherf Peter Paterson told the -year-old: "If you dont know this by now, I will tell you this is an extremely serious mater."Supplying class A drugs is a serious matter but to children aged  makes it a lot more serious."It could easily have killed them and you could be facing a charge of murder."Calling for background reports to be prepared before sentencing, the sherf warned Moffett that he would be remanded in custodyhe did not co-operate in the preparation of the reports and failed to turn up for appointments.Tessa Bradley, prosecuting, explained that the police report indicated that Moffett was "very popular among local youngsters" with a major feature being large groups congregating for the consumption of alcohol.She said that Moffett met a -year-old boy in Victoria Park, Galashiels, at around .pm on Thursday, October , and sold him the tablet.The fiscal described how the boys mother went to bed that night leaving her son playing video games.She said: "She got out of bed later on to get some medicine and found her son with large pupils and visibly shaking."The schoolboy received medical treatment and later confirmed that he had purchased the ecstasy tablet from Moffett.A search warrant was obtained for Moffetts home in Crumhaugh Road, Hawick, where pound in cash was recovered along with pink tablets and a mobile phone.Ms Bradley also described an incident on October  when another -year-old had taken what he believed to be an ecstasy tablet and after being found by his mother had to receive treatment at Borders General Hospital.The boy confirmed he had bought the tablet from Moffett.Moffett pleaded guilty to being concerned in the supply of compounds of ecstasy at his Hawick home between August  and October .Sentence was deferred until March  for the production of a Criminal Justice Social Work Report and a Restriction of Liberty Order assessment.
